data.title: Going for a Song
data.meta_description: An autobiography in lays and ditties
data.text:
Landlocked â€“ Jeff Hankins â€“ YouTube

On this 100th blog essay about songs of autobiographical significance, I hope I can be forgiven for doing something I havenâ€™t done in the other 99, being a little bit self indulgent, and choosing to write about one of my own songs.

The opening line of the song is indeed very autobiographically literal : â€˜I live a long way inland..â€™. And yes, the song is from the early 1990s, the time when we lived further from the coast than we had ever lived, smack in the heart of the continent of South America. OK, itâ€™s not that we had lived exactly in a seaside resort back here in South Wales, but maybe on the edge of consciousness thereâ€™s that awareness that the Bristol channel opening out as it does into the Atlantic.. ainâ€™t that far away. [Hereâ€™s a parenthetical reference to another of my songs. I am always delighted and sort of oddly taken by surprise every time I drive over the mountain from Merthyr to our village and find that, from the highest points of the road, on a clear day, I can indeed see the channel glinting in the distance and beyond it the hazy slopes of North Somerset hills. That delight finds expression in my song â€˜I see the seaâ€™]. Was I feeling the lack of that proximity, while paradoxically savouring with relish the exotic differentness of our new Latin living experiences? So it would seem, to some extent, from this songâ€¦

In that humid climate the late evening was of course the coolest time of the day, and quite often, once the kids had been showered, read to, put to bed, Sue was good enough to let me go for a wander through the streets of AscunciÃ³n, armed with a man-bag containing notebook, pen, bible, a novel, a cassette-playing Walkman (Bruce Cockburn, Laura Nyro, Juan Luis Guerra..). The lapacho-lined streets, the air itself, felt so alive and vibrant with new impressions that it was for me an extraordinarily creative time â€“ whether I scribbled half poems in a cafe-bar, or reached for a guitar when I got back homeâ€¦ Iâ€™m pretty sure that this song arose from just such an occasion as one of those late night walks, and (although this is not at all necessarily the mark of a songâ€™s quality, and perhaps more often quite the opposite!) it was indeed one of those all too rare occasions when the lyrics came without too much agonizing, sort of â€˜wrote itselfâ€™ as they say.(And no, Iâ€™m not suggesting spooky â€˜automatic writingâ€™ and certainly not â€˜divine inspirationâ€™! Iâ€™m just saying it flowed nicely, thank you very much.)

Some years ago I got together with a few friends to record a handful of my songs in a more serious way than the makeshift methods I had previously employed. Iâ€™ll always be indebted to MG particularly for the alchemy of his handling as we attempted to record â€˜Jacob wrestlingâ€™ â€˜Atlasâ€™ and â€˜Queen of Autumnâ€™. We worked hard on â€˜Landlockedâ€™ too, but somehow, failed to nail certain important stages of the process for recording this song, so no end product emerged. The kind friend who allowed her house to be used as this recording studio was of course subjected to listening to each song for multiples of practices and retakes. I remember distinctly her thoughtful engagement with this particular song and her saying to me ,with a smile, â€˜Itâ€™s not really about the sea, is it?â€™

And of course, no, itâ€™s not about the sea. As with so many things that grab the imagination in ways that make you want to â€˜tease something outâ€™ through lines of poetry or songs, itâ€™s â€“whether we are immediately aware of it or not â€“ often some symbolic or metaphorical significance that has really arrested us. Or me, anyway. I have a handful of songs that seem to start off innocuously enough with wistful celebrations of something or other, only to become compositions where, if I find myself performing them, I have to make an apologetic preface of â€˜sorry folks, another song about â€˜mortalityâ€™, I think..â€™! â€˜Landlockedâ€™ isnâ€™t one of those mortality songs though, and Iâ€™m not going to do all the interpreting right now, because that might take some of the fun out of listening and exploring; but I will confess â€“ and probably it is pretty explicit, isnâ€™t it â€“ that it attests to an awareness of the deepest of longings having been â€˜woken upâ€™ in my own spiritâ€¦ if that doesnâ€™t sound too pseudo mystical and pretentious!

In fact, Iâ€™ve just deleted a whole paragraph where I found myself â€˜explainingâ€™ the lyrics.. but I found that somehow in doing so I both insulted reader-intelligence, andâ€˜literalised itâ€™ to the point of dullness. Yes of course when I sing it it will always be most relevant to my own Jesus-focused experience, convictions and adventure, but thatâ€™s not to say that you dear listener will not discover other, extra, different, distinct, personal resonances within these fairly simple images and paradoxes. I hope something in it will engage you.

I think part of the reason why Iâ€™ve chosen this particular song to write about as number 100 in my blog thing, is because I think of this song as if it is one of my children (like all our songs feel like our offspring donâ€™t they?) but one who has been overlooked, considered a bit plain, perhaps. Itâ€™s not the most melodic of melodies â€“ perhaps even a rather limited musical canvas too with an (overly?) simple repetitive picking style; it seems to be trying to reach in a quirkier way than most of my output, for a slightly downbeat jazzy vibe (?). And it will never be anyoneâ€™s favourite (anyone but me, I mean!), I think. Ah, but I love it, poor little 30 year old song from the subtropical days.. and like the songsmith-dad to it that I am, I am both defensive of it and immensely proud of it!. And even here, back in Blighty, with the coast just half an hour down the A470, whoâ€™d have known, I still find some relevance in it! And still play it. For myself, generally ğŸ™‚

Iâ€™ve been a fervent* Sexsmithian ever since I first heard the wonderful cover version of â€˜Speaking with the Angelâ€™ recorded by Cry Cry Cry, the supergroup that comprised Dar Williams, Richard Shindell and Lucy Kaplansky (still a fabulous version, a fabulous album). So, as you do, I went out and found his first two albums freely available in all good music stores, and amazingly, around about the same time, I found out that he was visiting the UK and making an appearance at a Cardiff venue â€“ the intimate Clwb Ifor Bach. Reader, of course I went: and I was smitten by the songs â€“ here was a guy who knew how to construct neat, melodic 3 Â½ minute pop-folk songs that somehow avoided pop clichÃ© and generally said something.

Plus, one had to admit, there was something rather endearing about the man himself: slightly puffier and gawkier than your average rock star, a little bumbling and self effacing perhaps in the introductions, aware of his awkwardness, but ah, as he launched into each song, such surprising delicacy and control of delivery.

I saw him a year later in Cardiff too, somewhere down in the Bay, and hereâ€™s a little anecdote of sorts. I got chatting during the interval to another bloke who was on its own â€“ a solicitor, as it happened, who worked in the valleys, and whose musical tastes seemed similar to my own. Part of Ronâ€™s merchandise for the evening included an album he had recorded before launching his solo career: I bought it, of course, and my new solicitor friend also desperately wanted to buy it, but had brought no cash. I bought it for him, quite trusting his claim that he would repay me later. We exchanged addresses and he did indeed repay me later with a bank note in the mail a few days later. Since he also seemed quite a discerning listener, my new musical friend, I sent him, gratis, a CD of some of my own songs. I never heard from him again.

Back to Ron. â€˜Gold in them Hillsâ€™ comes I think from his fifth album (not counting that juvenilia one mentioned above), the production getting a little classier each time, and, blimey, the album containing two takes of this particular song, one of which featured Coldplayâ€™s very own Chris Martin!

And, come on, itâ€™s a beautiful song. A song I havenâ€™t got tired of, especially since â€˜rediscoveringâ€™ it as it came up randomly on a play list recently.

Mr Sexsmith often seems to construct songs around a hook that has perhaps the nature of a colloquial idiomatic phrase or aphorism. Nothing wrong with that. And you might think that that approach would lend itself to a certain triteness, but somehow he does generally manage to avoid it. This song is a song about hope, optimism, a kind of encouragement to open-minded attentiveness to possibilities. .. And already as Iâ€™m writing this, I can imagine that, especially if you donâ€™t know the song, my description is beginning to make it sound like something rather hackneyed like from an early Hollywood musical (â€˜forget your troubles come on get happyâ€¦etcâ€™) chivvying us on to an always-look-on-the- bright-side joviality. But I donâ€™t get that from the song â€“ for one thing thereâ€™s something a little ponderous about the rhythmic accompaniment and the melody that steers it away from tweeness. In its simple way it kind of argues for the transformative power of imagination, openness and even faith. â€œbut if weâ€™d only open our eyes/weâ€™d seeâ€¦ Though our troubles seem like mountainsâ€ â€˜raincloudsâ€™ can be â€˜fountainsâ€™. Fanciful optimism maybe, but the second verse continues in the same theme â€“ that while life might slow us down, pull us down even, we might achieve renewed perspective of fresh potentials..â€ And if we get up off our knees/ Why then weâ€™d see the forest for the trees/ And weâ€™d see the new sun rising/ Over the hills and horizonâ€. Donâ€™t lose heart- Give the day a chance to startâ€™ he sings first time around (and repeats at the end), then also â€˜Donâ€™t lose faith â€“ give the world a chance to say a word or twoâ€¦â€™ And of course the repeated â€˜Gold..â€™ clichÃ© remains a neat and clever shorthand for the idea of as yet unencountered treasuresâ€¦

Massively overbearing motivational jargon we can do without, but I think of this as a more delicate and thoughtful encouragement to a hope-full outlook.

Youll not be surprised, if youâ€™ve read previous posts, that the â€˜faithâ€™ aspect of such sentiments resonates. Sexsmith, it would appear from other songs, does have something of a churchy background and itâ€™s not implausible that something of some early years theology (!) informs his lyrical outlook.

*OK,If Iâ€™m honest, something of my Sexsmithian devoutness wavered around about the eighth or ninth albums, and there was for me a bit of a sad feeling to the short TV documentary film that was made in conjunction with the recording of the â€˜Long Player Late Bloomerâ€™ album, where we saw Sexsmith employing a new â€˜heavy rock credentialsâ€™ producer in a kind of desperate attempt to finally create a real â€™Hitâ€™ album. His demeanour, and some of the personal difficulties which accompanied these efforts, gave the enterprise a melancholy at odds with most of the music. Perhaps thatâ€™s just me. But I hope Ronald Eldon Sexsmith has been able to take advantage of his own musical exhortations â€“ â€˜donâ€™t lose heart/donâ€™t lose faith/ thereâ€™s gold in them hillsâ€™. Heâ€™s still performing anyway, I see.

Bridget St John -[02]- City-Crazy â€“ YouTube

When I was 18 or19, thereabouts, I fell in love with Bridget St John for, oh, a few months or so. Iâ€™ll tell it like I remember it. I was young, impressionable, full of that kind of romanticism which only late teens can be full of. Still with bits of A level Wordsworth in my head, springtime (of my life?) in my soul etc. And my soul, Iâ€™m afraid, was an incorrigibly dippy, â€˜sensitiveâ€™ one, far more Donovan and fairy tale gypsies and hawthorn blossoms than prog rock, heavy metal and sweaty electric guitar solos.. Letâ€™s call a spade a spade : I was musically quite narrow, with distinctive blind spots. My loss, no doubt, but there you have it.

I was very struck with the voice when I first heard her on the radio â€“ I do believe it was a Whispering Bob Harris radio programme: in my fuzzy memory I fancy I may even have â€˜recordedâ€™ the programme for some reason â€“ unless I am blending memories, on the same list I can recall the Incredible String Band â€˜Hedgehog Songâ€™, Ralph McTell singing something from â€˜You Well Meaning..â€™, and Judy Collinsâ€™s lovely â€˜Albatrossâ€™ song. Then this English girl â€“very English in fact, and how refreshing, oddly, to hear those home counties vowel sounds rather than someone trying to emulate a transatlantic twang. The voiceâ€™s quality Iâ€™ve heard referred to recently as â€˜cello-likeâ€™, which is not a bad description. The song was the first track on her second album â€˜Songs for the Gentle manâ€™ and it was called â€˜A Day awayâ€™. Of course it struck a chord: I was a gentle man (!), and this girl sounded like some of the posh undergraduates I was meeting in my first year at Uni: I could imagine long flowing skirts, headscarves maybe, floral caftans etc. In my defence, mâ€™lud, for my rather easy and shallow smittenness, she came with good credentials: whispering Bob said she sounded a lot like Nico (no idea who that was, then, but it sounded good) and he praised the lush orchestration of Ron Geesinâ€™s production (which now sounds to me both twee and overly ornate in its twiddly woodwind accompaniment) PLUS she had been signed on to John Peelâ€™s very own record label (Dandelion) so she had to be something special, didnâ€™t she.

â€˜Course, it wasnâ€™t just the sound and the voice that struck a chord in this gentle undergraduateâ€™s pathetic consciousness: there was the whole business of the pastoral romance, the nature-child, fantasy rural idyll business. After all, that â€˜Day Awayâ€™ song was just about that, wasnâ€™t it, leaving behind the tired artificial drabness of â€˜city lifeâ€™ to escape to free and natural surroundings â€“ the sea being the perfect example of freedom. [very funny, the allure of this idyll â€“ itâ€™s hardly as if I came from busy urban background! My own post-mining valley village nestled in a great deal of greenery!] And she evoked the lure of natureâ€™s freedom with just the right set of conscious poeticism likely to appeal to this average English undergraduate â€“ nice bits of personification (â€˜the winds scrawled her name through the stubble/as she ploughed through the pebbles to grab at the sea..â€™ etc, and of alliteration (â€˜ the wittering windâ€™, â€˜slow city suburbsâ€™)

So yes, dear reader, I bought the album, and a particularly loved the second track â€˜City Crazyâ€™ which lyrically was pretty much in exactly the same vein as the first song mentioned above, but with rather less orchestration I could work out the guitar and found that I could play it myself. I was, Iâ€™m afraid, still a little hooked and entranced by the sentiments of the nature-child fantasy: itâ€™s all here again, in simplistic pastel colours: city BAD (â€˜living in the cityâ€™s grip/I feel I lose control/as she reaches for my body/she is hoping for my soulâ€¦â€™ Hmm. And thereâ€™s a â€˜wilderness of buildingsâ€™ that â€˜tie us to their chaos/and try to drag us downâ€™. Whereas country/seaside GOOD:â€™ I need to sleep on shingle/yes I wish to step on sand/to move in time to tides and winds/and things I understandâ€™. What can I say? I loved it, I sang it. In that sense, I bought into its dream. And it was a pretty one, however naive.

(And it was the age, wasnâ€™t it? It was the very same idyllic dream that Joni Mitchell both flirted with and addressed in her first album: songs like â€˜Sisotowbell Laneâ€™ and â€˜The Dawntreaderâ€™ paint those â€˜naturalâ€™ images with a sense of beauty and delight; but in â€˜Song to a seagullâ€™ she faces the fantasy with a bold dose of realism rare for her generation of songwriters â€“ â€˜But sandcastles crumble, and hunger is human/ and humans are hungry for worlds they canâ€™t share..â€™)

If we think the idealism and sentimentality of Bridget St Johnâ€™s second album is naive, it is 10 times more so on the first, for me redeemed only by the extraordinary beauty of its title track â€˜Ask me no questionsâ€™. AND another thing to be said for Bridget St John â€“ she got better and better: the third and fourth albums were packed with some joyous tunes, and what felt like more of a â€˜rangeâ€™. By this time, Iâ€™d lost that first heady undergraduate dopey â€˜smitten-nessâ€™ and could just admire the music. Rumour had it that she went to America. She fell off oneâ€™s â€˜musical radarâ€™ for quite a while. She produced a fifth album called â€˜Take the Fifthâ€™ (a more meaningful title given her new American setting) which also had some lovely tracks, one of which â€“ with the help of a kind new friend on the Bridget StJohn Facebook site I recently stumbled across â€“ Iâ€™m learning to play.

So what about the early stuff? â€˜City Crazyâ€™ may not be part of my repertoire any longer? Can we still listen to it and enjoy it? Why not â€“ itâ€™s of its time. I think we can, in moderation.

My last (but one, I suppose) teaching post, and my longest, was at a Roman Catholic comprehensive school. Songs had a bit of a role there as much as in any secondary. An excellent music department ensured that for special assemblies, presentation evenings etc. the pupils were prepared and familiar with a range of appropriate worship songs. (One of my close colleagues abhorred the move towards â€˜evangelical country and westernâ€™ in RC worship, and would have been much happier with a few tasteful 17th century Marian anthems!) But Iâ€™m not thinking here about songs as used in our faith-school worship sessions â€“ there were few really â€“ teenagers simply do not sing together in that kind of setting â€“ Iâ€™m thinking more about some of the ways we employed songs for other purposes, in other settings involving teaching and reflection. And these two songs represent two incidents memorable to me for the way songs were used, in both cases, motivationally, you could say.

Every few years or so, all schools have to suffer a grand â€˜Inspectionâ€™ of course, and all the stops are pulled out (is that a musical metaphor? Pipe organ etc?) and everybody is on their best behaviour to put on a good show and to impress. Catholic schools have an extra dimension, of course, since some inspectors from church authorities will be looking to see (I presume?) that correct theology and appropriate ethical standards are promoted and maintained. The â€˜year groupâ€™ assembly (once a week) would be one way to demonstrate that, you might think. Our head of the sixth form was a woman for whom I have enormous respect and affection, and I was never more proud of her than on the morning of her â€˜showcaseâ€™ assembly opportunity during inspection week. While she might simply have gone for an easy option of choosing some smart kids to read out carefully articulated prayers, a little well practiced â€˜psalm performanceâ€™ sung by a couple of more confident A level music students etc, what she actually did, once we were all seated and expectant, was to put on the recording of Nina Simone singing â€˜Feeling Goodâ€™! It was perhaps unexpected, but the joy it elicited wasnâ€™t merely because of the surprise quality â€“ Iâ€™d defy anybody to listen to it even on a grey day, even in an educational establishment, and not to feel their spirits raised! Listen to it again and imagine how bravely almost-subversive it might have sounded in context! â€“ that unaccompanied opening, the introduction of the sensuous beat and bass riffs, the almost-rallying call to freedom (!), the semi-anarchic scat singing! Perfect Catholic assembly.

I learnt something that day, or at least was reminded of it forcibly â€“ that feel good music IS good theology in as far as it asserts the value of existence, the beauty and worth of life, and what on earth could be more important as a basis for any other spiritual, emotional or intellectual development? But itâ€™s more than just â€˜a life-affirming liftâ€™ because of its infectious jazziness, or Ms Simoneâ€™s seductive growlâ€¦ The whole thing in its simple but superb construction was an entirely appropriate choice to move the spirit forwards! Take, obviously, the refrain stirring us to consider lifeâ€™s fresh possibilities and potential: â€˜itâ€™s a new dawn, itâ€™s a new day, itâ€™s a new-life..!â€™ In its delicious verses of rhyming triplets, the song leads us to images of the natural world â€“birds, sun, breezeâ€¦. Fish, river, blossomâ€¦. Dragonfly, butterfly, stars, pine scentâ€¦. if weâ€™re even half aware of this catalogue to whom the singer calls, with whom she identifies, we get some sense of that intoxication, but the point of the identification is not just that weâ€™re fellow-creatures, but in the shared sense of â€˜freedom is mine!â€™. And by the time the song ends, we are totally with Nina â€“ â€˜And Iâ€™m feeling good!â€™ So thanks, Anne, for that memorable choice: your wisdom, taste and boldness, as ever! [Quickly and almost incidentally â€“ a Newley and Bricusse song?! Could we ever have guessed? They deserve more respect as songwriting partnership than hitherto accorded maybe!]

The other occasion is perhaps not dissimilar. On Monday mornings before classes began, those who felt so inclined would gather for 20 minutes or so of prayer and reflection. For quite a few of the years I was there, I was responsible for overseeing this slot, essentially just drawing up of rotas for whose turn it would be to lead which particular Monday reflection. I like to think I was moderately creative, imaginative and varied when it was my turn to lead, though I was cautiously aware too (perhaps as token ecumenical /protestant ?) of the need for my â€˜choicesâ€™ to make some valid scriptural or spiritual point. When it was the turn of my (dearly loved) head teacher Pete, he would often be far more adventurously imaginative, often bringing in unusual paintings, snippets from some piece of fiction and nonfiction he happened to be reading, but from it all he would generally weave something provocatively relevant to kickstart our prayers and our day. On one memorable occasion he said â€˜Iâ€™m just going to put this song on the CD player. Iâ€™m not sure what it all means, but we probably know what the opening words of each verse mean, and we can get the gist!â€™ It was Joan Baezâ€™s version of â€˜Gracias a La Vidaâ€™ from the album of the same name.

He was being modest about his linguistic ability, Iâ€™m sure, but there is a sense in which he was right: you just need to know for starters that each verse begins â€˜Thank you to Life!â€™ (and even better if you know â€˜que me ha dado tantoâ€™ means â€˜which has given me so much!â€™) and then you can just let the driving energy and the powerful vivacity of the song carry you along, if not with an equal sense of gratitude, then at least with that clear affirmation of the power of being alive which we got from â€˜Feeling Goodâ€™! And once again, you could say perhaps that this was indeed theology enough for a Monday morning, and if we could catch it, a perspective to set us up for the week, for life!

We didnâ€™t analyse it, we didnâ€™t need to. But if we hadâ€¦ there is even more in the detail to nourish our minds and hearts, I think. Six verses, basically life gets thanked for the following: eyes to see it all; the wonderful variety of the earthâ€™s sounds; words, language, communication [one of my favourite bits â€“ â€˜el sonido y el abecedario/Con las palabras que pienso y declaroâ€™ â€“ I too am still thankful for the alphabet of language!]; strength to travel, different locations and environments; oneâ€™s physical being; (and finally) the whole range of emotion and experience. This sixth and final verse is the most powerful of all, expressing gratitude for sorrow as well as laughter, aware that these are â€œ los dos materials que forman mi cantoâ€ (the two fabrics that comprise her song) and aware too that oneâ€™s own song is connected with the songs of others, the song of life. Although ostensibly she addresses these thoughts to a lover (mi buen amado), there is the sense that she is encompassing all humanity in this common song.

Though popularised by Joan Baez, the song was written by Violetta Parra. When Sue and I were learning Spanish (sort of) in Seville, our Spanish teacher Joanne told us that if we made it to Chile we must look out for some music by Violetta Parra. Why we couldnâ€™t have looked out for her music in other Latin countries, I donâ€™t know, but she was sort of right: I found nothing by Parra from the cassette â€“vendors on Asuncion streets, but plenty from similar vendors on the streets of Santiago. There is a greater rawness, even melancholy, about her style and work, more than Iâ€™d imagined, but the glory of this astounding original composition of hers shines through with a compelling authenticity. â€˜courseâ€¦ I still go back more regularly to the Baez version, for after all she was the one who has made it kind of â€˜accessibleâ€™ for all of us gringos.

So thank you God for these songs! Thank you (for) Life! Itâ€™s a new dawn, a new day, a new life. And generally, by the way, most of the time, Iâ€™m feeling good!

No, Iâ€™m not going to apologise for this one, even though I recognise that some of you will already be throwing up your hands in horror at what you see as a dippy sentimentalised show tune. â€˜But let me say, before we part..â€™ that I think that in this song, Schwartz has written a brilliant â€˜Goodbye/mutual appreciationâ€™ song. Since of course it was written for a specific musical, it is especially appropriate to be sung between two witches, one of whom is feisty, ambitious and green, the other of which plays (equally ambitiously?) to her dumb blonde stereotype. Despite it all, within it all, amazingly I still think there is something of truth and beauty in the song.

A few years ago, an old friend of mine turned 60. Iâ€™d kind of lost touch, if truth be told, but hereâ€™s where we bless Facebook. His wife contacted me and asked if I would jot a few words about my friend to be compiled along with othersâ€™ contributions for his birthday. I made reference to the fact that the sentiments within this song seemed somehow appropriate. In our early twenties we had shared a house together, and although there was much fun, it was not always easy because our personalities were quite different: at the end of the two years, though, Iâ€™d like to think (I can only hope that he agrees!) that we had learned something from each otherâ€™s different approaches â€“ even in our expressions of worship, and in the way we tried to live lives of service and faith. I still believe, I hope, that something of his earnest zeal and boldness stays with me, even now. â€˜Which one of you is Elphaba?â€™ asked his wife, after reading my contribution.

Iâ€™m not sure whether the Christian faith entirely endorses the kind of determinism proposed at the beginning of the song : â€˜Iâ€™ve heard it said/That people come into our lives for a reason/bringing something we must learn/And we are led to those who help us most to grow/If we let them/And they help us in returnâ€¦â€™ Hmm. Like Glinda, Iâ€™m inclined to say â€˜Well I donâ€™t know if I believe thatâ€™s true/But [thinking of a whole lifetime of friends who have left some kind of influence] I know Iâ€™m who I am today/Because I knew youâ€™... And ainâ€™t that the truth, dear reader? â€“ in some cases more than in others, obviously, so many we have met and journeyed with along the way have helped to mark and mould who we are today.

If youâ€™re familiar with this song, you will know that the two girls singing it to each other employ a bunch of similes to try to express the way that they feel mutually affected and influenced by each otherâ€™s presence in their lives â€“ I think the similes sound better than they mean, if that makes sense â€“ perhaps because they are images of natural objects (â€˜like a comet pulled from orbitâ€™..â€™ like a stream that meets a boulderâ€™..â€™like a seed dropped by a skybird..â€™ â€“ well, you get the idea) we naturally respond warmly to them , though Iâ€™m not sure they necessarily bear close analysis. But the one image that I do rather like is â€˜Youâ€™ll be with me, like a handprint on my heartâ€™. Ah, call me an old softie, I donâ€™t care; it gets me.

I can tell you when I first became aware of â€˜Wickedâ€™, I was returning up the M4, from London, having visited our elder daughter Mary who was spending a year doing some church and community work on a virtually voluntary basis. It choked me to leave her in a tiny bedroom at her digs, so you could say that I was in that vulnerable position, and the right frame of mind to be susceptible to the songsâ€™ whimsy and expressions of sentimentality. Driving back I listened to Elaine Paigeâ€™s Radio Two â€˜Musicalsâ€™ programme. (you might think, knowing me, that I would be a regular listener, but in actual fact this incident was one of only a small handful of occasions that I have ever heard the programme). Elaine mentioned a show that was taking Broadway by storm, and played three of the songs â€“ â€˜Wonderfulâ€™ I thought was okay, â€˜Popularâ€™ I thought was incredibly clever, and â€˜For Goodâ€™â€¦ You know, I canâ€™t entirely remember, but I suspect it made me cry.

Back at home, I checked out as much about the musical as I could on the Internet; I was lucky enough that I still had one child left at home young enough to share some of my enthusiasms. Sure enough, looking at relevant you tube clips, she got hooked, along with me, and so when â€˜Wickedâ€™ eventually transferred to London we planned our outing together! That involved: drive to Cardiff very early Saturday morning; â€˜Megabusâ€™ to London Victoria; matinee performance at the New Victoria Theatre; return journey and home in the early hours. Because the show was still relatively unknown, it had been easy to get tickets, and yes Idina Menzel (now Elsa-tised for life .!) was playing Elphaba. We were not disappointed, this 52 year old man and his 8 year old daughter.

One last word about the song: thereâ€™s some clever word play about â€˜goodâ€™ right throughout the musical eg. phrases like â€˜Thank goodnessâ€™ and â€˜goodness knowsâ€™ acquire layers of meaning; for in some measure the musical, and the novel of the â€˜Oz prequel eventsâ€™ on which the musical is (loosely?) based, are attempting to examine and question facile perceptions of goodness and evil [eg. In the Wizardâ€™s song he sings â€˜There are very few at ease/with moral ambiguities..â€™! Nice rhyme!] . And so that â€˜goodâ€™ wordplay is particularly relevant in this song, I suppose, playing on the dual idea of â€˜for goodâ€™ meaning â€˜with permanent effectâ€™ and â€˜ with obviously beneficial resultsâ€™. Clever.
